title: R43770
content: The hidden feature of federal crimes is secondary liability under 18 U.S.C. 2, where helpers and offenders face the same punishment. This secondary liability is similar to conspiracy, as society fears the crimes of several more than one. The aiding and abetting subsection is more frequently prosecuted than the causes subsection. Aiding and abetting under Section 2(a) requires the defendant to associate with the crime, participate in it, and actively contribute to its success by assisting in someone else's crime. The defendant must embrace and contribute to the success of another's crime to be convicted of aiding and abetting. Involvement in the crime can be minimal, as long as the accomplice aids in some way. The involvement in a crime can be minimal, as long as the accomplice aids in some way. Aiding and abetting law requires both knowledge and assistance with intent. A federal offense must be committed by someone else for aiding and abetting to apply. In Standefer, the Supreme Court ruled that aiding and abetting requires a completed offense before or at the time of the crime. Assistance given after the crime is a separate offense as an accessory after the fact. Accomplices sometimes avoid federal principles of secondary criminal liability by being charged as accessories after the fact, especially when there is a significant culpability gap between them and the primary offender. This typically involves three types of accomplices: victims, customers, and subordinates. "Victims" may include those who pay extortion, blackmail, or ransom monies, but not all victims qualify for this exception. The Hobbs Act outlaws extortion by public officials, but victims who are willing participants in corrupt schemes may be convicted for bribery or as accomplices to extortion. "Customers" like drinkers, bettors, johns, and drug addicts have escaped conviction as co-conspirators. Examples from the Supreme Court include United States v. Farrar and Rewis v. United States. United States involved customers like drinkers, bettors, johns, and drug addicts who were not prosecuted as aiders and abettors of unlawful activities. In Rewis, the Court ruled that mere bettors were not intended to be covered by the law. The Supreme Court cases United States v. Farrar and Rewis v. United States concluded that customers like drinkers, bettors, johns, and drug addicts were not prosecuted as aiders and abettors of unlawful activities. The federal gambling business statute and the Controlled Substances Act support the view that customers of drug traffickers or illegal gambling businesses cannot be prosecuted as coconspirators or aiders and abettors. Federal law now punishes traffickers severely for possession with intent to distribute, but not their customers. Since the enactment of the Controlled Substances Act, federal law punishes traffickers severely for possession with intent to distribute, while customers are typically charged with simple possession. The Supreme Court's Gebardi decision ruled that individuals agreeing to be transported for immoral purposes cannot be charged with conspiracy under the Mann Act. Lower federal courts have upheld this ruling but only in cases involving prostitutes. The Mann Act prohibits interstate transportation of women for immoral purposes, with lower federal courts following the Gebardi ruling but limiting it to cases where the prostitute only acquiesces to transportation. The Occupational Safety and Health Act does not allow prosecution of employees as aiders and abettors. In contrast, the federal gambling business statute condemns those who supervise unlawful gambling enterprises involving five or more individuals. Treatment of subordinates of drug kingpins remains uncertain. The federal gambling business statute condemns those who supervise unlawful gambling enterprises involving five or more individuals. There is uncertainty in how subordinates of a drug kingpin may be treated. Section 2(b) applies to defendants who work through intermediaries, whether witting or unwitting, guilty or innocent. Section 2(b) applies to defendants who work through intermediaries, whether knowingly or unknowingly, guilty or innocent. The intermediary's awareness of their actions varies, but liability is imposed only if the defendant and intermediary's actions together constitute an offense. The amendment to Section 2(b) in 1951 changed "causes" to "willfully causes" without clear indication of purpose. Speculation suggests the addition of "willfully" was to address a mental element observed by Judge Learned Hand in Section 2(a). The addition of "willfully" to Section 2(b) in 1951 was speculated to address a mental element noted by Judge Learned Hand in Section 2(a). Courts interpret "willfully" as a form of intentional behavior, where an individual intentionally uses someone else to commit a crime. Liability under Section 2(b) can be incurred even if the individual is unaware that the conduct is a crime. Federal courts sometimes consider a withdrawal defense. In aiding and abetting, liability can be incurred under §2(b) even if the individual is unaware that the conduct is a crime. Federal courts mention a withdrawal defense similar to conspiracy cases, where withdrawal is not a defense for the conspiracy itself but for crimes committed after withdrawal. The defendant must demonstrate affirmative action to establish withdrawal from a conspiracy. In federal cases, the withdrawal defense in aiding and abetting may be limited. Liability under §2(a) is avoided if the underlying offense is not committed due to the withdrawal of assistance. A completed offense is necessary for aiding and abetting. It is uncertain if a defendant can withdraw from aiding and abetting a crime, with varying results in different courts. In federal cases, the withdrawal defense in aiding and abetting may be limited. Proponents of a general withdrawal defense may claim support from recent dicta in Rosemond, where the Supreme Court explained the necessity for an accomplice to know of the substantive offense beforehand. The Tenth Circuit had upheld an alternative aiding and abetting instruction concerning a firearm charge in Rosemond's case. The Supreme Court clarified that an accomplice must be aware of the substantive offense beforehand to be held liable. There is no general civil aiding and abetting statute enacted by Congress. Therefore, there is no presumption that aiders and abettors can be sued in cases where a person sues a private defendant for violating a statutory norm. Courts have concluded that aiders and abettors do not incur civil liability for violations of various acts such as the Anti-Terrorism Act, Electronic Communications Privacy Act, Stored Communications Act, or RICO.
